text: I am working on a blog template. We does not have a website add-on. I am trying to add a Popular Post, Recent Post Filter in the Blog Listing page. But it seems to be not working. Is there any way I could add those filters with the same template design as my listing page.
Here’s a tutorial for creating a related posts section: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/tutorials/creating-a-related-post-section-with-hubl>
@importing the resulting values from a Custom Module into a CSS file… is that even possible? Objective = Theme styling from a global custom module that can set variables in the style.css file
Or am I forced to drop the style directly via the custom module into the header somewhere?

not 100% certain I’m fully understanding but going to try to answer: you cannot @import a custom module’s css file to get variables out of it.

I’m not sure of the specific scenario you’re dealing with but perhaps css custom properties will solve the issue for you. custom properties can be used across the page and don’t care about what file they’re in

beware though like everything good in the world IE doesn’t support it
<https://caniuse.com/#search=custom%20properties>
Dont think you can but I would LOVE the possibility to have a Custom "Options"  page that can be created for users to control these vars from a better interface than straight from CSS
For CSS I usually will just write it in a <style> tag in the same window
Actually what I’m trying to do is set a bunch of HubL variables in the Custom Module, then re-use those variables in the CSS file

But I think the right solution is to just build the entire <style> </style> section in that custom module and render that all in the header with the customizations (and overwrite the defaults coming out of the stylesheet)
